text: scientists sometimes make materials that
do things Mother Nature can't they
classify those substances as meta
materials maybe you've heard about what
researchers are calling an invisibility
cloak like Harry Potter's famous garment
it's a meta material in nature materials
can't make objects disappear from view
but some scientists have been able to
design substances that when an electric
or magnetic field is applied hide
objects from detection now a research
team at Cornell University has made a
new meta material a gel made entirely
from DNA in water it can go from having
a specific shape to being puddle like
and back again
the hydrogel is the scientists call it
remembers its original shape when it is
submerged in water it only loses form
outside of water these gels are the
softest ever made the Cornell team says
why is that inside the materials are
extraordinarily long single strands of
DNA 140,000 DNA bases long some of them
hydrogen bond to one another but they
mostly entangle forming bird's nest like
structures that can be viewed under an
electron microscope
it's these entanglements that keep the
gel together and give it its consistency
the gels are so soft in fact the Cornell
researchers think that they collapse
outside of water because of gravity
under water though buoyancy balances out
that gravity allowing them to maintain
their shape like the robot assassin
t1000 in the movie Terminator 2 the
researchers think the hydrogel might one
day flow through a tight space and
retake its original shape on the other
side but in the meantime they've got
their sights set on using unusual
materials in drug delivery and
electrical circuits
